member.name: M:EO.WebBrowser.NeedClientCertificateEventArgs.Continue(System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate)
member.summary: Continue the request with the specified client certificate.
member.remarks: Pass null to the certificate argument to continue the request without a certificate. Use this option if the server is set to "Accept certificate" but you do not have a client certificate to pass to the server. If the server is set to "Require certificate", then you must provide a valid certificate, otherwise the connection will fail.

member.name: T:EO.WebBrowser.NavigationTask
member.summary: An object that can be used to wait for a navigation task to complete.

member.name: T:EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask
member.summary: Provides the base class for a browser related task that can complete asynchronously.

member.name: M:EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask.GetDoneEvent(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a object that will be signaled when the task completes.
member.param: Whether to check the calling thread is the same as the thread that created the for to this is assoicated.
member.remarks: If checkThread is true, then this method check whether the calling thread is the same as the thread that created the to which this task is associated. An exception is raised if they are the same thread because waiting on the same thread that created the will stop the message flow thus can cause a deadlock. To avoid this exception, pass false to checkThread.

member.name: M:EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask.GetDoneEvent
member.summary: Returns a object that will be signaled when the task completes.
member.remarks: This method returns a object that can be waited on for the task to complete. However you should only wait on the returned from a worker thread. Waiting on the handle from the UI thread (the thread that creates the ) will stop the message flow thus causing a deadlock. For this reason, this method raises an exception if called from the UI thread. To avoid this exception, you can call and pass false to the checkThread argument.

member.name: M:EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask.WaitOne(System.Int32)
member.summary: Wait for the task to complete.
member.param: Timeout value in milliseconds, or -1 if to wait forever.
member.remarks: true if the wait was successful, otherwise false.

member.name: M:EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask.WaitOne
member.summary: Wait for the task to complete.

member.name: M:EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask.WaitAll(EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Wait for all the specified tasks to complete.
member.param: All taskes to be waited for.
Timeout value in milliseconds, or -1 if to wait forever.
member.remarks: true if the wait was successful, otherwise false.

member.name: M:EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask.WaitAll(EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask[])
member.summary: Wait for all the specified tasks to complete.
member.remarks: true if the wait was successful, otherwise false.

member.name: M:EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask.WaitAny(EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Wait for any of the specified tasks to complete.
member.param: All taskes to be waited for.
Timeout value in milliseconds, or -1 if to wait forever.
member.remarks: If any of the tasks has completed before timeout expires, this function returns the index of that task. If no task has completed before timeout expires, this function returns WaitHandle.WaitTimeout.

member.name: M:EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask.WaitAny(EO.WebBrowser.WaitableTask[])
member.summary: Wait for any of the specified tasks to complete.
member.remarks: If any of the tasks has completed, this function returns the index of that task. Otherwise it does not return.

member.name: T:EO.WebBrowser.RequestCanceledException
member.summary: The exception thrown when a request has been canceled.

The exception occurs when the request that your are handling has been canceled by the browser engine (for example, the JavaScript code inside the page redirects to another page). You can safely ignore this exception in your code since the primary purpose of this exception is to abort your handling code.

remarks.para: When throwOnError is false, the object will not be thrown. However you can access the exception object through , through which you can obtain more information about the JavaScript exception.

When a JavaScript value is returned to the .NET code through this function, primitive JavaScript values are automatically converted to their corresponding .NET types. For example, a JavaScrit string will be converted to a System.String object. For non-primitive values, a value of type is returned. Note that the return value maybe of type that derives from . For example, a JavaScript array will be returned as a .
See here for more information on how to use this function.

member.name: P:EO.WebBrowser.WebView.UnloadDelay
member.summary: Specifies the amount of the time the WebView should wait before it destroys after it has been taken off the screen.

remarks.para: After a is taken off the screen (when its parent window has been destroyed), the will still be kept in the memory for a short period of time before it is completely destroyed. This delay allows you to move the from one parent window to another parent window without having to destroy and recreate the , thus keeping the status of the .

Use this property to specify the duration of this short period in milliseconds. The default value is 300. Set this property to a negative value to destroy the immediately after the parent window has been destroyed.

member.name: P:EO.WebBrowser.WebView.CustomUserAgent
member.summary: Gets or sets custom user agent string.

remarks.para: Set this property to override the default user agent string. The default user agent string is the same as Google Chrome browser except for specific version number might be different.

Many web servers use user agent string to detect client browser type and serve different version of HTML code based on the detected browser type. As such if you change the user agent to a completely "unknown" user agent string, the server may serve the "wrong" HTML code which can result in page not displaying correctly. As such it is suggested that your custom user agent string is not something completely different, but a string that append extra information to the default user agent string. To find out the default user agent string, you can visit a website that displays your user agent string, such as whatsmyuseragent.com.

member.name: P:EO.WebBrowser.WebView.AcceptLanguage
member.summary: Gets or sets the Accept-Langauge header entry.

remarks.para: By default, the "Accept-Language" header entry in the HTTP request is set to "en-US". If the server supports multiple languages, it can use this entry to determine which version of the page to send. Use this property to override this value. For example, if you set it to "de-DE" and load Google's home page, then the German version of Google's homepage will be loaded.
See here for a list of the language.

member.name: E:EO.WebBrowser.WebView.LoadCompleted
member.summary: Occurs when a page has loaded successfully.
member.remarks: Note that the page is considered being loaded sucessfully even if the server returns an HTTP status other than 200. For example, if the page you are trying to load requires log in but you choose cancel, then the Web server may returns "HTTP 401: Unauthorized" along with an error message indicating that you are not authorized to access the page. In that case the HTTP request is considered to be completed sucessfully (as oppose to other errors such as "server not found", "request canceled", in which cases the event will be fired). To determine whether the page has been loaded "normally", you can check whether the HttpStatusCode property of the event argument is 200.
